Award.AwardTitle: CCF-BSF: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Coding and Information - Theoretic Aspects of Local Data Recovery

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies fundamental problems in data coding that can improve the efficiency of distributed storage systems by increasing data reliability and availability while reducing storage overhead compared to existing industry standards. The results of this research can benefit storage applications ranging from financial, scientific monitoring, and signal processing to social networks and sharing platforms. The new combinatorial, coding, and information theoretic tools developed in this project will be incorporated in course curricula in the respective institutions of the principal investigators.

Data coding with locality, the focus of this project, is a rapidly developing area of coding theory that was initially motivated by applications in distributed storage, and has links to many areas of network science (e.g., index coding and network coding) as well as to computer science. This project advances the theory and practice of data coding with local recovery by investigating broad implications of the locality constraint in coding problems. These include studying new error-correcting code families and their decoding, fundamental limitations on the code parameters and capacity bounds under the requirements of local data recovery. The newly designed coding schemes developed in this project will be validated through implementation and evaluation in simulated computer environment, aiming at enhanced performance of data coding in current industry solutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Information written in large-scale storage systems that support operation of data centers is distributed across several nodes. To prevent information loss in the event of node failure, which occurs on a daily basis, the data is encoded using special methods called erasure coding schemes. This project is concerned with constructing erasure codes based on algebraic methods as well as with implementation and evaluation of different coding schemes based on the parameters of existing distributed storage systems. The outcomes of the project include new constructions of erasure codes for several versions of the general problem that involve communication costs attaining the theoretical bounds for optimality of node repair. Among new methods developed in the project is application of transformations between algebraic curves that support efficient erasure correction. A transformation, shown schematically in the attached figure, creates a repair group for the failed node (denoted by P). By addressing a small number of other nodes it becomes possible to reliably recover the lost information, supporting the failure-free operation of the system.

Another research direction addressed in the project, constructs coding schemes that recover the lost data by transmitting as few bits as possible between the nodes in the storage cluster. A bound on the "repair bandwidth", derived in earlier works, serves as a benchmark for this group of problems. This project resulted in several new coding schemes that attain this bound, thereby constructing optimal data regenerating codes for several scenarios. A new version of the repair problem analyzed in the project, deals with the model of storage system wherein the nodes are arranged in racks (which corresponds to the actual setting of the system), whereby communication within the rack is less taxing on the system resources than transmission of data between the racks. For this version of the system, termed clustered storage, the project develops algebraic methods of constructing optimal codes with efficient recovery of erased data.
